Award.AwardTitle: Preparation of Research Collections to Deposit in Museums
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will organize, preserve, and archive an important collection of fossil and extant specimens of stickleback fish from Alaska and California. Sticklebacks have long been a critical model system in evolutionary biology, and are known for their complex mating behavior and diversity among populations in terms of morphology and life-history. This collection, which was assembled since 1975, represents extensive phenotypic diversity in stickleback fish, and therefore this data-source is crucial for current and future comparative or experimental research on sticklebacks in particular, and evolutionary and behavioral processes in general. Of particular value are the fossil samples, as they are central to gain a better understanding of the timing of evolutionary dynamics, including trends in trait relationships and their role in shaping stickleback diversity. This project will make this collection accessible to researchers nationally, and internationally. It will provide important training and research opportunities in basic and applied sciences (e.g., Department of Fish and Wildlife).

The fossil specimens will be deposited in the University of California Museum of Paleontology; the extant specimens will be deposited in the Ichthyology Collection of the California Academy of Sciences. The samples and associated records will be indexed and linked to field notes and associated databases will be assigned museum specimen numbers. Curating and depositing these specimens will make them available to the general science community. The preservation of this research collection will ensure the continued use of this valuable resource, and preparation of sample records will involve high-throughput scanning, accuracy-editing of labels, curation of microstratigraphic data as well as map coordinate data. Sample records will be linked to an existing limnological database, as well as the Alaska Department of Fish and Game records for the Alaskan samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this award was to archive specimens of fossil and modern Threespine Stickleback fish (Gasterosteus) that had been collected using National Science Foundation funds for research by Michael A. Bell during about 50 years of research. During this time, the Threespine Stickleback emerged as a textbook example of evolution and a valuable tool in evolutionary genetics and genomics. Most of Bell’s research compared skeletal traits among natural populations from multiple sites in relation to environmental variables or used variation through time within individual natural populations at intervals ranging from one generation in modern populations to 5,000 years in a fossil sequence. Thousands of samples, each usually comprising hundreds to thousands of individual stickleback had accumulated in Bell’s lab. The samples had been carefully documented, and many research papers were published using these samples, but the samples have additional research value.

Many of the modern populations that Bell sampled are extinct or have evolved dramatically within the last few decades in response to human disturbance. Thus, some of Bell’s samples document the properties of extinct populations that cannot be sampled any more. Many others can be used to compare to more recent samples to study rapid evolution. The samples can be used for new comparisons among populations that Bell never made but would be too expensive to do in the future if new samples had to be collected. Similarly, new research that Bell did not do with the fossils might be done in the future by others using his samples. While it would be possible to make new fossil samples, that would be expensive and time consuming. These research opportunities could only be realized by depositing Bell’s samples and accompanying data into museums, where they can be studied in the future by other investigators.

This project resulted in all of Bell’s samples being deposited in two museums: fossils in the University of California Museum of Paleontology (UCMP), modern stickleback in the California Academy of Sciences (CAS). Each sample is accompanied by scanned electronic files of field notes, maps, and other documents. Databases of the environmental, geographical, or geological context of each sample were created and edited for errors and clarity. New documents explaining the databases were also created or edited for clarity. The skeletal data used in Bell’s papers were deposited with the specimens and other files for use in the future.

The fossil samples were all delivered to the UCMP, and some are currently being studied by a graduate student there. Most of Bell’s samples from modern Alaskan populations were delivered to the laboratory of Prof. Frank A. von Hippel, University of Northern Arizona and are on loan to him for use in his ongoing research. The remainder of Alaskan samples were retained by Bell and are on loan to him at University of California, Berkeley, where he is a Research Associate and Visiting Scientist, to study rapid evolution in lake populations. About half of the samples from modern California populations are on loan to Prof. Eric Palkovacs, University of California, Santa Cruz for his ongoing research on them. However, all of the samples belong to UCMP and CAS.

Now Bell’s samples can be studied by any qualified investigator using the usual museum practices. Each sample of modern stickleback and each fossil specimen has a museum catalog number. These numbers can be used to link each specimen to databases for the samples and to previous research in which it was used, Thus, while this project did not produce any new research, it has preserved Bell’s research samples with the information needed to use them for future research by others.

Theoretically important results based on these samples have literally become “textbook examples.” In the future, these textbook examples can be verified by reference to the original specimens and associated information, and new textbook examples can be produced using them. However, more applied studies to study rapid evolutionary responses to human environmental impacts can also be produced. These samples can be used to identify populations with suitable traits for molecular genetic and genomic studies, as before. Thus, taxpayer dollars invested in Bell’s research has produced samples that other investigators can use for their own pure and applied biological research.
